CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-3 - Reasonableness of pre-trial detention)
JUDGES: Armen Harutyunyan;Kristina Pardalos;Krzysztof Wojtyczek;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Pauliine Koskelo;Ksenija Turković
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is a former Minister of ORG and at the material time he headed a political movement called “ Civil Disobedience ” .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE criminal proceedings were instituted under Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( money laundering ) in respect of the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested and on CARDINAL DATE the GPE and ORG of GPE ordered the applicant ’s detention for a period of DATE , upon an application by the investigator , taking into account the nature and the dangerousness of the imputed offence and the fact that the applicant , if remaining at large , could abscond and obstruct the investigation by exerting unlawful influence on the persons involved in the proceedings . The applicant objected to that application , arguing that the investigator had failed to submit any wellfounded arguments in support of the allegation that he would abscond or obstruct justice , whereas he had no previous convictions , was known to be of good character , had a permanent place of residence and stable social life , and was a well - known public figure . ORG decision stated that it could be contested before ORG within DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal , raising similar arguments .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to uphold the decision of ORG , finding that the nature and the dangerousness of the imputed offence , sufficient reasons to believe that the applicant could obstruct the investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE and ORG of GPE extended the applicant ’s detention by DATE , upon an application by the investigator , finding that the applicant , if remaining at large , could obstruct the investigation , abscond , exert unlawful influence on the persons involved in the proceedings and commit another offence . ORG decision stated that it could be contested before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the applicant lodged an appeal , raising arguments similar to those previously raised .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to uphold the decision of ORG , finding that the nature and the dangerousness of the imputed offence , the particular circumstances and complexity of the case ; the investigative measures to be carried out and the applicant ’s behaviour , namely his refusal to give any testimony , which was a factor slowing down the investigation , gave sufficient reasons to believe that the applicant could obstruct the investigation by exerting unlawful influence on the persons involved in the proceedings and also abscond .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE and ORG of GPE extended the applicant ’s detention by DATE , upon an application of the investigator , on the same grounds as before . ORG decision stated that it could be contested before ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal , raising arguments similar to those previously raised

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigator decided to replace the applicant ’s detention with a written undertaking not to leave his residence and to release him in view of the fact that the investigative measures would take some time and it was no longer necessary to keep the applicant in detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to leave the applicant ’s appeal of DATE unexamined in view of the fact that he had been released .
